Ramesh: the tragedy of our entrepreneurs is that they will accept 36 conditions from the Austrian govt for mining coal, but won’t from India
Ramesh: At the WTO India was the last man standing. India’s leaders profit from elections at home when they take a stand for the environment
Ramesh: India could have transitioned to sustainable energy 20 yrs ago but didn’t due to a morality play.
Ramesh: today solar provides 30% of Germany’s power after a 10 year transition. India, with a more favorable resource endowment, shd lead.
Ramesh: Germany is leading in solar energy despite having winter weather for 9 mo of the year. What wd happen if India went seriously solar?
Ramesh: these tiny voices will drive India to make sensible choices between economic growth and environmental devastation.
Ramesh: forest-dwellers stopped bauxite mining in Orissa; democratic process defended the rights of a tiny minority.
Ramesh: democratic processes come from tiny populations whose voices cannot be ignored.
Ramesh: forest-dwellers are voting themselves out of India because forests are not protected.
Ramesh: India is settling debates over Bt crops, nuclear power, forests through democracy.
Ramesh: transgenic crops promise high heat and salinity tolerance. India follows precautionary principle. Bt cotton yes; Bt rice, wheat, no.
Ramesh: the model of economic growth is therefore the central issue for India. 10 million jobs a year. so it must be rapid and low-carbon.
Ramesh: Environmental policy follows historical logic.  The EPA Act of India (1986) only followed after Bhopal (1984).
Ramesh: today the logic of economic growth is so overwhelming that everyone chooses economic growth at cost of environmental futures.
This is a major economic argument for protecting the climate.  Ramesh: "We are protecting livelihoods, not lifestyles."
Ramesh stresses Chipko as a women’s movement for protecting livelihoods.  Same w/ mangroves, forests, beaches: livelihoods are at stake.
Ramesh stresses public health as rationale for India taking environmental action: pollution at root of rural indebtedness for health

@keosulli @jtonra love it. thanks for tweeting, and good luck to you all!
@keosulli @jtonra global places like Columbia & Galway can play important roles in setting out a model — but allies are everywhere
@jtonra @keosulli @duchas_ie tell us more!
.@keosulli @jtonra the scale of repressed stories, endangered archives around the globe dwarfs the scale of our profession.
.@keosulli @jtonra not that Elkins isn't a heroine: but we need a “citizen science” for history that seriously commits to repressed stories
.@keosulli @jtonra “citizen science” for history: instead of subsidizing more Caroline Elkins, build communities of documentation in Nigeria
.@keosulli @jtonra the idea is @elotroalex's: “citizen science” for history
.@keosulli @jtonra “citizen science” for history: instead of harvesting stories, plant communities that continuously document their own.
.@keosulli @jtonra “citizen science” for history: instead of harvesting stories, plant communities that continuously document their own.
@keosulli @jtonra avoiding science envy may be an affective problem. respect for those who don't code is important for #dh.
.@keosulli @jtonra we talked at columbia last night about building a “citizen science” for history
.@keosulli @jtonra — and use open-source to partner w grassroots communities collecting oral/local/endangered histories for themselves
.@keosulli @jtonra the best future is one built from collaboration, where historians learn to talk to CS about their data, borrow tools
.@keosulli @jtonra the bad scenario is a zero-sum game where future historians train in algorithms and NOT oral history.
.@keosulli @jtonra  most of us, in our careers, borrow from as many methodologies as possible
.@keosulli @jtonra we think not: there can be a division of labor, some recovering subaltern voices, others working on algorithms.
.@jtonra @keosulli #dh has to talk about oscillation as a skill only to fend off those afraid of a cliometric death of narrative.
.@jtonra @keosulli others reason this kind of oscillation is even banal as a historical skillset. we always drill and contextualize.
@keosulli folks like Fredrik Jonsson, @finnarne, Libby Robins, & Paul Warde are at the forefront of a revolution in this kind of thinking.
.@jtonra @keosulli major credit to @nowviskie for the theory of creative iterating/oscillation as #dh practice
.@jtonra @keosulli this is something #dh folk teach all the time — oscillating between tool and other kinds of analysis, iterating.
.@jtonra @keosulli we talked at Columbia yesterday about tacking between micro/macro, the individual/event in a bigger context, as #dh skill
@keosulli choose the theme first — then the question becomes, what is the appropriate periodization for that institution, crisis
@keosulli that is the point to which we write — to encourage historians to talk about why they choose their themes
@keosulli would love to hear how your students think about history and climate change — where can stories help? which ones help the most?
@keosulli awesome.  would love to hear how your students think about history and climate change — where can stories help?
@keosulli so an institution can be a movement, a family, an identity. it is interesting if they govern housing, land, water, or if not.
@keosulli Colin Ward, David Graeber wd say an institution like the state is human, we create new ones by working together on new things
@keosulli new institutional economics (doug north et al) have inspired a lot of my colleagues, although we take it in other directions
@keosulli @historyatgalway say more!
@keosulli chronology has to be appropriate to the subject — 80-200 yrs for many institutions, empire, capitalism. 100k yrs for genome.
@keosulli good question. we talk about super-long “big” and “deep” hist but i practice “moyenne duree”, 80-200 yrs.
@ThomasJundt  When you are next in PVD I would love to geek out about international history
@ThomasJundt ohai.  I was just reading your smart UNESCO article.
@keosulli @historyatgalway awesome! standing by. :)
